title: Great Railroad Strike
description: The Great Railroad Strike of 1877 began in Baltimore and spread nationwide, marking the first major labor uprising in American history. Workers protested wage cuts amid economic depression, leading to federal troops being deployed to restore order.
modernConnection: This strike established precedents for federal intervention in labor disputes and highlighted the ongoing tensions between workers and corporations that persist in modern labor relations and union organizing efforts.

title: Edison's Electric Light Bulb Patent
description: Thomas Edison received his patent for the incandescent light bulb in Menlo Park, New Jersey, revolutionizing lighting and laying the foundation for the electrical industry.
modernConnection: Edison's innovation sparked the modern electrical grid system and established the research and development model that continues to drive technological advancement in Silicon Valley and beyond.

title: Standard Oil Trust Formation
description: John D. Rockefeller formed the Standard Oil Trust in Cleveland, creating America's first major monopoly and controlling 90% of oil refining in the United States.
modernConnection: The Standard Oil monopoly led to antitrust legislation that continues to regulate big tech companies like Google, Amazon, and Meta, addressing similar concerns about market concentration and consumer protection.

title: Brooklyn Bridge Opens
description: The Brooklyn Bridge opened as the world's longest suspension bridge, symbolizing American engineering prowess and connecting Manhattan and Brooklyn.
modernConnection: This engineering marvel established America as a leader in large-scale infrastructure projects, inspiring modern megaprojects like smart cities and sustainable transportation networks.

title: Haymarket Affair
description: A labor protest in Chicago for the eight-hour workday turned violent, resulting in deaths and the trial of eight anarchists, becoming a symbol of the labor movement.
modernConnection: The fight for worker rights and reasonable hours continues today in debates over work-life balance, gig economy regulations, and the push for a four-day work week.

title: Statue of Liberty Dedicated
description: The Statue of Liberty was dedicated in New York Harbor as a symbol of freedom and democracy, welcoming millions of immigrants to America.
modernConnection: The statue remains a powerful symbol in modern immigration debates, representing America's identity as a nation of immigrants while highlighting ongoing discussions about border policy and refugee acceptance.

title: Sherman Antitrust Act
description: The Sherman Antitrust Act was passed in Washington D.C., becoming the first major law to regulate monopolies and trusts in American business.
modernConnection: This landmark legislation continues to shape modern antitrust enforcement against tech giants, pharmaceutical companies, and other industries accused of anti-competitive practices.

title: Carnegie Steel Company Founded
description: Andrew Carnegie founded Carnegie Steel Company in Pittsburgh, which became the largest steel producer in the world and dominated American steel production.
modernConnection: Carnegie's vertical integration strategy is mirrored by modern tech companies like Apple and Amazon, which control multiple aspects of their supply chains and distribution networks.

title: Pullman Strike
description: The Pullman Strike began in Chicago when railroad workers protested wage cuts and high rents in company housing, leading to a nationwide railroad boycott.
modernConnection: This strike highlighted issues of corporate control over workers' lives that resonate today with company towns created by tech giants and debates over employer-provided housing and benefits.

title: Spanish-American War Begins
description: The Spanish-American War began, marking America's emergence as a global imperial power with territories in the Caribbean and Pacific.
modernConnection: This war established America's role as a global superpower, setting precedents for international intervention that continue to influence foreign policy and military engagement worldwide.

title: J.P. Morgan Forms U.S. Steel
description: J.P. Morgan created U.S. Steel Corporation in New York, the world's first billion-dollar corporation, by consolidating Carnegie Steel and other companies.
modernConnection: Morgan's creation of the first billion-dollar corporation established the template for modern mega-mergers and the formation of today's trillion-dollar tech companies like Apple and Microsoft.

title: Wright Brothers First Flight
description: Orville and Wilbur Wright achieved the first powered flight at Kitty Hawk, North Carolina, launching the aviation age.
modernConnection: The Wright brothers' innovation spirit parallels modern aerospace advances, from SpaceX's reusable rockets to the development of electric aircraft and urban air mobility solutions.

title: Ford Motor Company Founded
description: Henry Ford founded the Ford Motor Company in Detroit, which would revolutionize manufacturing with the assembly line and make automobiles affordable for the masses.
modernConnection: Ford's mass production methods transformed manufacturing globally and continue to influence modern automation, robotics, and the electric vehicle revolution led by companies like Tesla.

title: San Francisco Earthquake
description: A devastating earthquake and fire destroyed much of San Francisco, leading to major advances in building codes and urban planning.
modernConnection: This disaster led to modern earthquake engineering and emergency preparedness systems that inform current responses to natural disasters and climate change adaptation strategies.

title: Model T Production Begins
description: Ford began mass production of the Model T in Detroit, making automobiles affordable for ordinary Americans and transforming transportation forever.
modernConnection: The Model T's democratization of transportation mirrors how electric vehicles and autonomous driving technology are reshaping mobility and urban planning in the 21st century.

title: NAACP Founded
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was founded in New York City to fight for civil rights and racial equality.
modernConnection: The NAACP's founding established organized civil rights advocacy that continues today through organizations fighting systemic racism, voting rights, and social justice reform.

title: Triangle Shirtwaist Fire
description: A fire at the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory in New York City killed 146 workers, mostly young immigrant women, leading to major workplace safety reforms.
modernConnection: This tragedy established modern workplace safety regulations and labor protections that continue to evolve with new challenges in gig work, remote employment, and industrial automation.

title: Federal Reserve System Created
description: The Federal Reserve Act was signed in Washington D.C., creating America's central banking system to provide financial stability and regulate monetary policy.
modernConnection: The Federal Reserve continues to play a crucial role in managing economic crises, inflation, and financial stability, as seen during the 2008 financial crisis and COVID-19 pandemic responses.

title: Panama Canal Opens
description: The Panama Canal opened to shipping, dramatically reducing travel time between Atlantic and Pacific oceans and establishing American dominance in global trade routes.
modernConnection: The canal remains vital to global trade and demonstrates how infrastructure investments can reshape economic geography, similar to modern debates over broadband networks and supply chain resilience.

title: World War I Begins
description: World War I began in Europe, initially with American neutrality, but eventually drawing the United States into global conflict and transforming America into a world power.
modernConnection: WWI established America's role in global conflicts and international diplomacy, setting precedents for modern military interventions and international cooperation through organizations like NATO and the UN.
